abstract.p: ewireless is developing method for cell phone users to be connected to advertisers for data on products and services by dialing 333; will introduce service in Chicago metropolitan area; calls will be free for callers; company plans to expand service to other cities; participating advertisers, including Chase Manhattan, Dell and FedEx will use radio and billboard ads to promote service (S)

block.p: In another example of how marketers are capitalizing on new technology to deliver sales pitches, a company is developing a method for users of wireless telephones to be connected to advertisers without dialing an ''800'' number. The company, ewireless, of Highland Park, Ill., plans to introduce today in metropolitan Chicago a service named #333 with participating advertisers that include Chase Manhattan, Dell and FedEx. Radio commercials and billboards will direct drivers with wireless phones to dial #333; those who do will be connected to call centers to obtain information on the products and services sold by the advertisers. Dean Becker, chief executive at ewireless, said the calls would be free for the callers, and that the service would be expanded to other cities, including Boston and New York, by early next year.
